user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtMem2BinFileCmp:
```c
bool UtMem2BinFileCmp(const void *Memory, const char *Filename)
{
    FILE *       fp;
    const uint8 *MemByte = Memory;
    int          FileByte;
    bool         Success;
    uint32       i;

    Success = true;
    if ((fp = fopen(Filename, "r")))
    {
        for (i = 0; (FileByte = fgetc(fp)) != EOF; i++)
        {
            if (MemByte[i] != FileByte)
            {
                Success = false;
                printf("UtMem2BinFileCmp: Miscompare in file: %s, byte offset: %lu, expected: %u, found: %u\n",
                       Filename, (unsigned long)i, (unsigned int)MemByte[i], (unsigned int)FileByte);
                break;
            }
        }
        fclose(fp);
    }
    else
    {
        Success = false;
        printf("UtMem2BinFileCmp: Error Opening File: %s, %s\n", Filename, strerror(errno));
        UtAssert_True(false, "UtMem2BinFileCmp: Error Opening File");
    }

    return Success;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtMem2BinFileCmp:
typedef uint8_t   uint8
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
#define UtAssert_True(Expression, __VA_ARGS__) UtAssertEx(Expression,UtAssert_GetContext(),__FILE__,__LINE__,__VA_ARGS__)
...
UtAssert_CaseType_t UtAssert_GetContext(void)
{
    return DefaultContext;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: printf("UtMem2BinFileCmp: Error Opening File: %s, %s\n", Filename, strerror(errno));
explanation: I did not include other pointer occurrences because they already use const or cannot reasonably be const: the parameters 'const void *Memory' and 'const char *Filename' are already const-qualified; 'const uint8 *MemByte = Memory;' is const-qualified; the FILE API (fopen, fgetc, fclose) requires a mutable FILE * (so declaring fp as const FILE * would be incompatible with these standard functions); and strerror has a prototype that returns char * (the implementation does not provide a const-qualified return), so although the returned string is only read here it cannot be made const without a local cast/assignment. Therefore only the shown fragments (declaration/assignment of the FILE pointer and the direct use of strerror(errno) in printf) warrant investigation for Rule 8.13 compliance.
